newsitem.title: FRANCE: French stocks open higher on unchanged Fed rates.
newsitem.headline: French stocks open higher on unchanged Fed rates.

text.p: French shares pushed ahead after opening with narrow gains on Wednesday, spurred on by the U.S. Federal Reserve's decision to hold interest rates unchanged, traders said.
The blue-chip CAC-40 index was up 20.36 points or 0.76 percent at 2,771.47 at 0815 GMT while the CAC-40 May futures contract was up 29 at 2,772 from Tuesday's close.

Positive sentiment from Wall Street's gains buoyed the market but investors were staying on the sidelines as long as political risk remained a factor, ahead of France's two-round parliamentary election on May 25 and June 1.
CLF-Dexia France adds 2.8 percent to 551, cheered by comments on a bullish start to 1997 and a forecast of 100 billion francs of new lending by the end of the year.
Thomson-CSF rises 1.03 percent to 195.5 francs, helped by news of a new frigate sale to Saudi Arabia, estimated at around eight billion francs.
More than half the frigate's contract value would be in naval electronics, a source familiar with the deal said.

Seita drops 2.2 percent to 208.5 francs. The company warned of an all-out price war among cigarette makers but said Seita was ready to meet the threat. It expects to post "satisfactory" operating profits this year.
Banque Nationale de Paris rises 3.26 percent to 266. A trader said a French broker held a breakfast meeting with the bank and fund managers.
The share price has recently been driven up by speculation over mergers and aquisitions.

BNP's buyout offer of BNP-Incontinentale is being challenged by minority shareholders, assisted by corporate governance specialist Sophie L'Helias, over the terms and lack of financial information on the deal.
